Graphic abstract The newly fabricated Ni/Cu-TiO2 enhances the water splitting by improving the generation of oxygen vacancies (VOs) in the photo-reaction and the consumption of VOs in the thermo-reaction. Oxygen vacancy (VO) is a significant component in defect engineering. The present work reports the anchoring effects of initial VO for further loading modifications and the reducing capacity of photo-induced VO for pure water splitting. Herein, we propose Ni-loaded Cu-doped TiO2 (NCT) materials by successive doping and loading. The continuously added Ni ions should accumulate around the VOs and gradually grow into complete nickel oxide crystals, achieving a higher average valence state of the Ni species. NiO crystals can be detected on a 0.5% NCT sample, while the structure of Ni2O3 has been confirmed with a higher nickel mass ratio. Moreover, the introduction of nickel oxide effectively improves the photochemical and electrochemical performance by the interface charge separation, finally reaching an H2 yield of 30.6 μmol/g-cat on 0.5% NCT for VO-based photo-thermal coupling reaction, which consists of VO generation in photo and VO consumption in thermal environment. In situ infrared spectroscopy further indicated that the presence of high valence state nickel oxide hindered the H2 formation but effectively promoted the conventional oxidizing reaction, with an H2 yield of 20.6 mmol/g-cat in a methanol–water reaction on the 2.0% NCT material. In summary, VO controls the morphological structure of Ni loading and produces diverse effects for reactions with dissimilar mechanisms, which provides a novel way to design modifications for promoting various chemical reactions. Keywords Oxygen vacancy Nickel oxide Water splitting Photo-thermal coupling reaction DFT calculation 1 Introduction Amid the energy crisis, solar energy utilization for hydrogen evolution and carbon-based fuel has garnered growing attention [1,2]. Functional semiconductors have been widely applied, in which TiO2 has been studied [3] for decades. Based on various modifications, effective solar fuel production has been achieved, contributing to green energy engineering [4]. Defect engineering has been regarded as an effective method for material improvement [5]. The defects are always considered as the missed lattice atoms, in which the oxygen vacancy (VO) has an indispensable position in the previous investigation. In general, VOs possess the advantages of whole visible spectrum absorption, efficient charge separation and surface site activation [6]. Different from conventional catalysis effects in the field of photo- and electro-catalysis, Minot et al. [7] has presented that the VOs should result in the dissociative adsorption of H2, H2O and CO2, and further proved that an H2O molecule dissociate into H* and OH* with the O end filling VO by calculation. Additionally, Bi et al. [8] reported that VO-abundant TiO2 presented a self-healing effect on H2O splitting, as confirmed by synchronous illumination X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and pointed out that photo-induced VOs exhibited reactivity with hydroxide radicals by experiments. Furthermore, Zhang et al. [9] reported a novel chemical cycle for pure water splitting, which is described as the direct thermal application of photo-induced VOs for effective solar utilization. The above-mentioned reaction was designed into two steps around the photo-induced VOs. The first process is the generation of photo-induced VOs under illumination, and the second process is the consumption of VOs by reducing H2O to H2 while simultaneously restoring O defects. The above method could integrate photo energy (low wavelength solar) and thermal energy (high wavelength solar) and garner extensive attention. Yoon et al. [10] enhanced the mechanism by isotopic tracing, Fu et al. [11] achieved CO2 methanation with the help of photo-induced VO and Zhou et al. [12] displayed VO-activated CO2 splitting over a Zn-Ge-O semiconductor. Since the metal doped materials had been proposed to enhance the photoreaction properties for H2 production [13], the metal loading is designed to promote the thermal process. Typically, among the previous articles, Ni species, such as metallic nickel, nickel oxide and nickel hydroxide, have been frequently utilized as effective catalysts in various fields. Liu et al. [14] had proposed Ni/In2O3 material for improving the selective hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to methanol, the CO2 convention and space–time yield of methanol had been obvious enhanced with the increased defects by Ni loading. In addition, NiO is widely used as the heterojunction structure with a substrate, and a reported amorphous NiO-loaded g-C3N4 photocatalyst enhanced visible-light-driven H2 generation by nearly 430-fold [15]. Besides, Jouini et al. [16] had applied gamma-ray irradiation to promote the phase change from NiO to Ni2O3 for better photoreactivity. Moreover, Ni(OH)2 nanosheets have been widely applied as the positive electrode material in rechargeable alkaline batteries, which plays a significant role in the field of electric energy storage devices [17]. A steady CoNi-MOFs-modified BiVO4 material has been reported to enhance the photoelectrochemical water splitting by Wang et al. [18], and the structure successfully brings additional reaction sites and increases the photocurrent density by 260%. In summary, the nickel series plays a critical role in disparate enhanced mechanisms with its various forms. Thus, the selection of the correct Ni species is important for Ni-based modifications. Besides, recent studies have extended the functions of VOs within material engineering, as prepared VOs have exhibited the ability to anchor doped metal ions. Ling et al. [19] doped VO-abundant CoO with Ni atoms, and both characterization and theory calculations have proposed that the Ni dopant gradually began to cluster around the defects. Moreover, numerous studies on graphene have presented evidence that metal ions should anchor onto nitrogen defects [20], which also indicates that defect engineering should dictate further modification processes. Since the utilized precursor in the present work has owned the surface defects during the calcining process [21], the relationship between the inherent VOs and formed Ni species should be investigated. Furthermore, the enhanced mechanism of loaded sample in photo-thermal coupling reaction has not been reported in the previous work. And how the different forms of the Ni load influence the hydrogen evolution also remains a question to be solved. A complete optimum proposal has been proposed in this paper. The VO-abundant Cu doped TiO2 (Cu-TiO2) sample, was applied as the substrate, and further modified to provide various Ni-loaded Cu-doped TiO2 (NCT) samples (the mass ratio of Ni to substrate ranged from 0.1% to 2.0%). The inherent VOs anchored the Ni atoms and formed various nickel oxides with different valence states. A NiO structure was detected in 0.5 wt% NCT (a mass ratio of Ni:TiO2 equal to 0.5%), and the presence of Ni2O3 was confirmed on a higher Ni-loaded NCT sample. The prepared NCT samples exhibited great improvements in photon harvest, charge transfer and electrochemical properties compared with bare substrates, resulting in an enhanced mechanism. The highest H2 yield of 30.6 μmol/g-cat was achieved on 0.5 NCT in pure water splitting, which was nearly 40 times greater than that of the bare TiO2 material. In situ time-resolved diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) further pointed out that the Ni2O3 structure should be harmful to the VO-based water splitting reaction. In contrast, increasing the Ni mass benefits the methanol–water oxidizing reaction, and 2.0 NCT exhibited a H2 production of 20.6 mmol/g-cat. Thus, it is clear that the interaction between the VOs and loaded ions should determine the formation of loading and further contribute to chemical reactions of different principles. We believe that the present work provides a new focus in the field of material engineering and leads to great expectations for VO-based reactions for effective solar utilization. 2 Experimental Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2), nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2), tetrabutyl titanate, sodium hydroxide and glacial acetic acid were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. All of the above chemicals were analytical reagents (ARs). Reference P25 titanium(IV) oxide (TiO2) nanoparticles were from Degussa. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.1 Fabrication of the materials The TiO2 and Cu-TiO2 samples were prepared using the sol–gel synthesis method. Tetrabutyl titanate (10 mL) was dissolved in 30 mL of absolute ethanol and named solution A. A mixture of glacial acetic acid (4 mL), deionized water (5 mL) and absolute ethanol (30 mL) was named solution B. Solution B was poured into solution A at 273 K with continuous stirring until a gel formed. Then, the stabilized sols were dried in an oven at 373 K for 12 h, and the resulting xerogels were milled into a powder and calcined in a muffle furnace at 673 K for 3 h. Finally, the sample was cooled in air, and the prepared TiO2 was collected. For the synthesis of Cu-TiO2 as well as pure TiO2, metal nitrate was added to achieve a mass ratio Cu:TiO2 = 0.5% during the preparation of solution B. NCT samples with five different mass ratios (0.1 wt% to 2.0 wt%) were manufactured by the wet impregnation method. A 1 g aliquot of prepared Cu-TiO2 was dissolved in 50 mL of 1.0 M NaOH solution, and an appropriate amount of 0.1 M Ni(NO3)2·6H2O solution was added under intense stirring. After 12 h stirring, the filtered mixture was washed with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water until the pH reached 7.0. Then, the resulting solution was dried at 373 K for 12 h followed by calcination at 623 K for 3 h to obtain NCT sample. 2.2 Experimental measurements Three gas-sample experiments were utilized to evaluate the performance; H2O splitting experiment, isotopic tracing experiment and in situ DRIFTS experiment. Three different elaborate experimental platforms were designed for the above experiment, and detailed experimental measurements have been shown in the Supporting Information 1. 2.3 Electrochemical characterization Electrochemical measurements were carried out in a typical three-electrode electrochemical cell at room temperature with 0.1 M Na2SO4 as the electrolyte. The suspension of catalysts was prepared by mixing 5 mg of catalyst with 400 μL of ethanol and 40 μL of Nafion (Sigma-Aldrich, 5 wt%) followed by sonication for 1 h. A thin film of material prepared by drop-casting catalyst ink (5 μL suspension) on a polished glassy carbon electrode (0.5027 cm2) was used as the working electrode, and the counter and reference electrodes were Pt foil and Ag/AgCl, respectively. 2.4 Characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS) images were obtained using an HT-7700 X-MAXn65 transmission electron microscope with an acceleration voltage of 120 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by using a Cu K α radiation source (K α = 1.540598 Å) operated at 40 kV and 100 mA. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) was performed on an iCAP6300 ICP emission spectrometer. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were performed on a Bruker A300 at room temperature using the powdered samples placed in a hermetic quartz tube. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) of the thin film samples was performed using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (200–800 nm, SHIMADZU UV-3600). The photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved PL emission spectral patterns were collected on an Edinburgh Instruments FLS 920 equipped with a 405 nm electro-photoluminescence (EPL) excitation light. To record the changes, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained with an ESCALAB 250Xi electron spectrometer with an Al K α 1486.6 eV source from Thermo Fisher Scientific. The Ni K edge (8333 eV) extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra were collected at the 1W1B beamline at the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF), China. 2.5 Theory calculations Density functional theory (DFT) was utilized to calculate all reaction energies [22]. All spin-polarized calculations were performed within the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP). The project-augmented wave (PAW) method was used. The valence electronic states were expanded in plane wave basis sets with an energy cut-off of 400 eV. The Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid was set to 3 × 3 × 1. The convergence threshold for the self-consistent-field iteration was set to 10−4 eV. Geometry optimizations converged when the force components were less than 0.01 eV/Å. The preliminary mechanism of the VO-based photo-thermochemistry reaction on the Cu-TiO2 sample has been confirmed in previous work [23]. Typical water splitting from a VO-based photo-thermochemistry reaction consists of two processes: the photoreaction and the thermal reaction, which can be written as follows: (1) Ti 4 + + Cu 2 + + O L 2 - → Ti 3 + + Cu + + V O + 1 / 2 O 2 ( p h o t o c h e m i s t r y ) (2) Ti 3 + + Cu + + V O + H 2 O → Ti 4 + + Cu 2 + + O L 2 - + H 2 ( t h e r m o c h e m i s t r y ) Here, OL represents the O atom in the lattices on the surface. A detailed verification of the mechanism is shown in Supporting Information 4. The isotope experiment introduced into the VO-based reaction confirmed that O2 escaped from the surface in the photoreaction process. Preliminary data have been reported [23]. An extended experiment was proposed, and the results are shown in Fig. S16, which further supports the mechanism of the formation and consumption of VOs. To enhance the reaction mechanism on NCT samples, the XPS spectra of the Ni 2p state in the original, illuminated and cycled stages of 0.5 NCT are shown in Fig. 5 (a). Four obvious peaks in the original state, located at 855.87, 873.53, 862.00 and 880.00 eV, were regarded as Ni 2p3/2, Ni 2p1/2 and their satellite peaks, respectively. The main Ni peaks underwent a positive shift during the photoreaction and returned to their former place after the thermal process, implied that the Ni2+ cations may translate into Ni3+ species under illumination by losing an electron, which is different from the behaviours of the charge changes on the Cu and Ti atoms. Considering the possible positions of the energy band, the enhanced mechanism on the NCT during the photoreaction process is described in Fig. 5(b). The energy band position of TiO2 was determined, and an impurity level appeared in the band gap by Cu doping. As soon as Ni oxide was loaded onto the surface of the Cu-TiO2, abundant electron transport bonds formed at the interfaces, and an effective band gap of 2.25 eV was formed. Since the lattice defects and nanoparticle size greatly influence the band structure [37], the gradually generated NiO owned a changing band gap. During the photoreaction, the photo-generated electrons and holes were produced and naturally separated from the substrate and loading attributed to the internal electric field. The photo-generated electrons on the CB of NiO transfer to the CB of the substrate owing to its more negative potential further resulted in the reduction of Ti and Cu cations. Moreover, the photo-generated holes on the valence band (VB) of Cu-TiO2 moved to the VB of loading and were captured by Ni2+ ions and OL corresponding to the formation of Ni3+ ions and VOs. Hereto, an enhanced mechanism on the NCT samples under illumination has been explained by the hybrid theory and can be written as the following expressions: (3) hv → h + + e - (4) Ti 4 + + Cu 2 + + 2 e - → Ti 3 + + Cu + (5) 5 h + + Ni 2 + + 2 O L 2 - → Ni 3 + + V O + O 2 Notably, the main charge changes occurred on the different sites compared with the Cu-TiO2, and the differently positioned VOs should directly affect the related reaction with H2O molecules. The natural separation exhibited an enhancement in H2 yield compared with the original substrate. The detailed calculation pathway is shown in Fig. 5(c). The thermal process contains three steps: H2O adsorption, H2O decomposition and H2 formation. The loading and substrate are expressed as the Cu-TiO2 (101) and NiO (200) surfaces, and the step position represents the total energy of the calculated models. Once the VO formed, the calculation starts from the pure surface with a single VO. It is clear that the two models undergo different energy changes; NiO mainly suffers an energy crisis of 1.93 eV in the decomposition process, while Cu-TiO2 bares a larger energy barrier of 4.32 eV in the H2 formation process, resulting in H2 appearing on the defective NiO more easily. The photo-thermal coupling reaction was achieved by the combination of H2O and photo-induced VOs, which played a crucial role in H2 production. On a low Ni-loaded sample such as 0.1 NCT, the dispersed Ni atoms focused around the surface defects and formed an imperfect Ni oxide (or single Ni atom form), which provided little performance improvement. Moreover, the added Ni atoms promoted the reduction in Cu ions due to charge compensation. Then, the increased Cu+ ions hindered the photo-induced VO generation in the Cu−O−Ti bonds. Thus, the 0.1 NCT sample presented a weaker signal than the Cu-TiO2 substrate. Furthermore, as the Ni oxide load gradually increased towards a higher valence state, the 0.5 NCT seemed to be an inflection point. The N2O3 structure in the 1.0 NCT and 2.0 NCT should form a stable bond with the H2O molecules and confine the breaking of hydroxide radicals, which is the key step in the production of H2 molecules. Hence, 1.0 NCT shows a lower H2 yield compared to 0.5 NCT, and production on the 2.0 NCT sample decreased further. The above results indicated that the over low or high valence-state Ni loading do harmful to the VO-based reaction, and a suitable load rate NCT material is necessary to be design for enhancing the H2 production. The reaction of CH3OH with H2O was carried out for comparison. Since the reaction was operated at 623 K, the CH3OH would become active and mainly produces H2 and carbon oxide, the decomposition and reformation of methanol can be written as follows [44]: (6) CH 3 OH → CO + 2 H 2 (7) CH 3 OH + H 2 O → HCOOH + 2 H 2 → CO 2 + 3 H 2 The in situ DRIFTS on the NCT samples exposed to methanol and water are shown in Fig. 7 . The peaks that changed in the first 30 min were marked and assigned to the various species. The bands at 1060 and 2977 cm−1 correspond to the C–O and C−H stretching of the methanol species (CH3OH), while the bands at 1200 and 2940 cm−1 were assigned to the C−O and C−H stretching of formic acid (HCOOH) [45]. The presence of CO and CO2 were confirmed by the bands at 2110 and 2320 cm−1, respectively [10]. Additionally, an obvious peak from the O–H group appeared at approximately 3700 cm−1. Comparing the intensities of the peaks after 30 min on the different NCTs, the 2.0 NCT had the strongest signals, indicating the fastest chemical reaction rate. Furthermore, 2.0 NCT presented a special enhancement at the positions of 1200 and 2940 cm−1, which pointed to the abundant HCOOH species. The formation of HCOOH in Eq. (7) can be extended as follows [46]: (8) CH 3 OH + 2 h + → HCHO + 2 H + (9) HCHO + H 2 O + 2 h + → HCOOH + 2 H + Since the above equations require the participation of positive charge carriers (h+ ions), the presence of Ni3+ ions promotes the formation of HCOOH, resulting in a sharp increase in the H2 yield. The 0.1 NCT presents the Ni3+ generated and production boosted comparing to 0.5 NCT, and 2.0 NCT had a H2 production of 20.65 mmol/g-cat, which was nearly 2.67 times greater than that of the 1.0 NCT sample due to the further increase in Ni3+ species. Besides, the HCOOH is widely considered as the precursor of the CO, thus, there showed the increasing ratio of CO to H2 in the produced gas on NCT samples (from 0.057 on 0.1 NCT to 0.228 on 2.0 NCT). The above discussion on the production of H2 clearly points out that the low valence Ni species is beneficial to a VO-based reaction such as the pure H2O splitting experiment, and high valence Ni species may improve other reactions, such as methanol reformation. Since the VO-based reaction can be regard as a typical reduction reaction for reducing the H2O to H2 by using photo-induced VOs and the CH3OH reaction is assigned to an oxidizing reaction, the above experimental phenomena pointed to an inference that the NiO and Ni2O3 can function in different reaction fields. Moreover, in this paper, the formation of the two mentioned species was mainly attributed to the interaction between the VOs and the added ions, pointing out a new way to design these materials for improving the ideal reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, the morphological structure of Ni oxide loading was controlled by VOs during the preparation process and has diverse effects on photo-induced VO-based reactions and conventional catalytic reactions with different forms. The initial VOs showed the ability to anchor the added Ni ions, and the actual load weight was closely related to the number of inherent VOs. Benefit from the absorption of VO sites to Ni atoms, the change of Ni loading is sensitive to the mass ratio of Ni. With increasing Ni mass ratio, the Ni clusters grew larger and underwent a change in the internal valence state of the Ni species. The EXAFS pattern further presented details on the presence of the Ni2O3 structure in a higher Ni-loaded NCT. The NCTs exhibited a great improvement in photon harvest, charge transfer and electrochemical properties compared with the substrates. Combining the valence changes and energy band potential, an enhanced photoreaction mechanism on the NCT was proposed, and the photo-induced electron-hole pairs in the interface were naturally separated to produce photo-induced VOs. These materials have been tested in photo-induced VO-based pure H2O splitting reactions and the methanol–water reaction. Notably, the presence of high valence state Ni species is harmful to the VO-based reaction by preventing the breaking of the O−H bonds but effectively promotes the conventional catalysis reaction by higher concentration of carriers. Plain speaking, the formed NiO effectively improves the H2O reducing to H2, and formed Ni2O3 is more favourable for oxidation. The highest H2 yield of 30.6 μmol/g-cat in the VO-based pure H2O splitting reaction was achieved on 0.5 NCT, which was nearly 40 times greater than that of bare TiO2. Moreover, the H2 yield for the methanol–water reaction increased as the Ni mass increased, and 2.0 NCT showed a H2 production of 20.6 mmol/g-cat. Thus, we can conclude that the interaction between the initial VOs and loaded ions should determine the formation of loading and further contribute to the chemical reactions of different principles. We believe that the present work provides a new focus in the field of material engineering and leads to great expectations for photo-induced VO-based reactions for effective solar utilization. coredata.dc:description: Oxygen vacancy (VO) is a significant component in defect engineering. The present work reports the anchoring effects of initial VO for further loading modifications and the reducing capacity of photo-induced VO for pure water splitting. Herein, we propose Ni-loaded Cu-doped TiO2 (NCT) materials by successive doping and loading. The continuously added Ni ions should accumulate around the VOs and gradually grow into complete nickel oxide crystals, achieving a higher average valence state of the Ni species. NiO crystals can be detected on a 0.5% NCT sample, while the structure of Ni2O3 has been confirmed with a higher nickel mass ratio. Moreover, the introduction of nickel oxide effectively improves the photochemical and electrochemical performance by the interface charge separation, finally reaching an H2 yield of 30.6 μmol/g-cat on 0.5% NCT for VO-based photo-thermal coupling reaction, which consists of VO generation in photo and VO consumption in thermal environment. In situ infrared spectroscopy further indicated that the presence of high valence state nickel oxide hindered the H2 formation but effectively promoted the conventional oxidizing reaction, with an H2 yield of 20.6 mmol/g-cat in a methanol–water reaction on the 2.0% NCT material. In summary, VO controls the morphological structure of Ni loading and produces diverse effects for reactions with dissimilar mechanisms, which provides a novel way to design modifications for promoting various chemical reactions.
